awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Consequences of Environmental Stochasticity for the Spatial Dynamics of Savanna-Forest Transitions
awd_abstract_narration:
Changing temperature and rainfall patterns globally will have  major effects on vegetation patterns, in some cases shifting the nature of ecosystems dramatically with consequences for wildlife, and for the services that natural systems provide to humans.  These “critical transitions”  are possible outcomes of environmental shifts in a wide variety of systems, including the savanna and forest transitions that this project will address, in which changes in frequency of fires can be especially important in changing the nature of these key ecosystem types. Building on previous work by the project leaders, this research will develop and apply state-of-the-art mathematical models, in concert with empirical studies, to predict how changing environmental conditions will mediate shifts in the savanna-forest boundary.  This project will also enhance education and training at multiple levels, including the training of a postdoctoral fellow; development of graduate and undergraduate research projects; and data visualization through collaboration with artist and educator Neil Goldberg.

The potential for multiple stable states, respectively forest and savanna, in vegetation systems has been previously demonstrated, combining empirical work with dynamical systems models.  The introduction of spatial effects leads to systems of partial-differential or partial differential-integral equations, including stochastic influences, which of course are more complicated to analyze, but are crucial for predicting the shifts of boundaries.  This project will develop and apply new methodologies drawn from non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, and will generate novel mathematical results, in particular in terms of fluctuations around the mean-field limit, developing new approaches to these stochastic systems, and applying a  novel landscape-flux approach. A key element will involve the training of a truly interdisciplinary postdoctoral fellow to be fluent both in the mathematical dimensions of the project and the ecological data analysis.

This award is funded jointly by the MPS Division of Mathematical Sciences (DMS) through the Mathematical Biology Program and BIO/DEB through the Cluster of Population and Community Ecology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project made contributions both to fundamental mathematics, and to the application of that mathematics to a range of observed or possible phenomena involving natural systems.  The examples explored involve a specific class of ecological systems, but the potential applicability extends not only to other ecological systems, but also to socio-economic and coupled socio-economic ecological systems in which the emergence of spatial pattern is important, and further, in which factors like climate change, pandemics or market forces  might lead to the loss of resilience.

 

One of the main achievements was deriving a new class of vegetation models that account for spatial extent.  We introduced models that scale up the interactions taking place at the level of individual trees and grass patches to the ecosystem scale, generalizing and extending previous modelling frameworks for savanna-forest biomes. Moreover, these spatially extended models then allowed us to ask and answer more detailed questions about the structure of ecosystems and how this structure might depend on topographic heterogeneity (e.g. in rainfall, slope or other factors) or the fire or tree spread rates.

The project extensively studied how heterogeneity impacts previous predictions and findings from mechanistic forest-savanna models. For example, there is a pronounced rainfall gradient in sub-Saharan Africa, ranging from wet, highly forested regions in West Africa to drier, savanna-dominated regions in East Africa. Analysis showed how these macroscale vegetation patterns emerge naturally and can be explained by a "front-pinning" mechanism, as previously demonstrated in simpler models. However, detailed analysis highlighted that alternative stable states may exist even when heterogeneity is accounted for, such as states with sharp forest-savanna boundaries (as currently observed empirically) being multi-stable with purely forest-dominated states. Work also showed that our spatial models can produce heterogeneous forest-savanna mosaics when there is sufficient resource pressure on forest trees.

 

Finally, the project used a powerful methodology, the landscape-flux method, from statistical physics to understand ecosystem transitions with alternative stable states and quantify ecosystems' resilience to disturbance. In a series of papers, it was shown how this new method could quantify the likelihood of transitions from a savanna to a forest state (or vice versa) in an ecosystem subject to random fluctuations (such as from the climate system). These methods can also be used to define "early warning indicators" of transitions, which was shown in several well-known ecological models, including forest-savanna, coral reef and lake ecosystems. This greatly expanded the rigorous examination of such phenomena, which has been a cutting-edge topic in ecological theory in recent years.
